item.title: Hegel's Aesthetics
item.description: Aristotle, Poetics. Penguin Books, 1996. 5 Some artists imitate better people, others imitate worse. This is what distinguishes tragedy from comedy. 6 The source of art is the natural delight human beings take in viewing the most accurate images of objects which in themselves cause distress when we see them, e.g. ’low’ species of animals, corpses. This is a natural spontaneous impulse; it arises in early childhood. 7 Poetry is divided into two varieties aligning with corresponding types of character; more serious poets, such as Homer imitated fine actions of fine persons in hymns or encomia others of inferior tendencies imitated inferior persons.
